description.text:
Part of EurIng Andy Southern's New Year Resolution 1 design uploaded per day. This is a rack for holding a SQUARE 45mm jar. This compliments yesterdays design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:621728 45° Spice Rack for CSec 45mm Jar Settling Upscaled for the design of 26th January 2015:
(Complimentary) Ø74mm 25°(ish) tilt Jam Jar Seperation Device:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:651609
Primary reason for this is to allow any kind of precipitate to settle down to the bottom corner. Above are photos of the printed job (I'm having issues with damp near the printer) before I depeak and Acetone Vapour Bath (AVB) to give it a smooth and alluring finish. +++I'll vapour bath these both together with tomorrow's design+++ I've attached the CAD files for you all to play with in PTC / Creo Elements. Have Fun. No rights are reserved for this, though if you're handling precious metals with this, feel free to send a cheque on for, I don't know 0.1% or something. -Let me know what you think- EUR ING Andy Southern.

title: Fox
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a fox! We made him for our friends at http://www.foxsmart.club/ . Fox was made with some wonderful and very affordable filament from FoxSmart. We think he will be a great print for anyone who enjoys foxes as much as we do (some live by our office), or the people at FoxSmart! Does your kid like foxes? Print them out a fox! Do you like foxes? Print yourself a fox! If you would like to see a specific animal, please leave a comment for us and we will make it. Check out our website at:
http://www.yourwildworld.com/

For single extruders:  
Use the fox1pc.stl file, no supports are needed. We used a raft, 2 shells and 10% infill.  
For dual extrusion:  
Use the Fox_Body2.stl and Fox_Parts_2.stl files. We used Replicator G to merge the files. It was printed with PLA at 10% infill with no supports and 2 shells. 210 degrees C prevents excess oozing and stringers pretty well. We made a multi colored piece of filament with our Parfait Technology for the Fox_Parts_2.stl file to get the black and white color changes. You can use just white and color in the black with a marker, or you can manually change colors at the correct time.

author: LucidPsykosis

description.text:
The framework to build a cheap circular LED display. This is based around the led matrix displays using the MAX7219 driver chip, these boards cost about £1 each and can be found on ebay by searching for MAX7219. The display is driven from a microcontroller such as an Arduino.
There is a bracket to mount an Arduino Uno to the top or bottom of the display, assuming you use 16 display segments. Display overview and build - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cu6kMsd_Y8M

The display can use any number of screens but it is designed for 16, if you use more or less than this the flat brackets won't work as they are very specific with the hole separation. The smaller clips can accommodate a bit of variation but probably only +- 2 displays. For a bit more info there is an instructable for this.
http://www.instructables.com/id/Circular-LED-Display/

description.text:
A didgeridoo in a box!
This design packs the sound of a digeridoo into a box the size of a large book and sounds almost as good as its wooden counterparts. Here is a recording of me playing it (I still have a lot of practicing to do)
https://soundcloud.com/didgprinter/first-recording

Some assembly required When I printed this on a Prussia i3v 10" printer with a heated bed, the large bottom and top pice warped a bit. I was planning on using epoxy or some similar glue to join the two halves but ended up resorting to hot glue since it could fill the gaps. I ended up coating the bottom half with hot glue and placing it face down on an aluminum foil sheet on a kitchen griddle.
When the hot glue remelted, I pushed the two halves together.
After that, hot gluing on the mouthpiece was easy.

comments.text:
LOL, never thought of folding up a didgeridoo ;) I might make one of wood, my printer is not big enough for you version and the acoustics probably will be a little better.
You might want to send this in for the contest:
http://www.thingiverse.com/challenges/MakeItLoud

description.text: This is my remix of a bowden extruder for the 3up. Very much in progress like the hotend mount. author: collintravers

description.text: Can be used in the bathroom.

It is an easy to clean drying rack for NeilMed Sinus Rinse. Let it dry during the day and if you have company over you can always hide it under the sink.  
I made this because I only have one bathroom. So having the sinus rinse rack tapped to the mirror out in the open when guest come is not really appealing... So I made one that is movable and also has a drip tray to avoid water everywhere.  
I added the SolidWorks files I used to create this. Including the Sinus Rinse bottle and nozzle. Just on the off chance someone with SolidWorks wants to modify it with text or something.

I would recommend printing with as thick of a shell as you can, to make sure it is watertight.  Also use at least 10% fill so it does not collapse. I used 0.3mm step height in the shown picture, but 0.4mm would work fine as well. It may look like it is going to fall during printing but I never needed to add supports (printed 3 times). You may need to file the feet to get it perfectly level.

title: DaVinci 1.0 Extruder Heatsink Cooling Shroud
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
There have been other fan shrouds created, but I wanted something to focus most of the airflow onto the heatsink while trying to absolutely minimize airflow disturbances in the nozzle/heater block area.
Drawing air directly over a hot, just-printed ABS layer is a recipe for warping and delamination! This shroud uses the stock heatsink, and fits as snugly as possible while still allowing clearance for the heating cartridge and thermistor wires. It will clear the carriage when installing, but you must carefully route the heater cartridge wires against the chamfered corner of the shroud as shown in the photos. You also might want to apply kapton or metal tape to several areas around the extruder metal housing where there are air leaks. UPDATE: New pictures added to show location of cutouts for proper routing of thermistor wires. Also pictures to show air leak locations that should be sealed! PLEASE READ THE INSTRUCTIONS FOR OTHER IMPORTANT INFORMATION.

IF YOU DON"T READ ALL OF THE INSTRUCTIONS - PLEASE READ THIS FIRST PARAGRAPH! After experimenting with the fan blowing both ways, it has become clear that it MUST be mounted to suck air up through the shroud - NOT blowing air into it. If blowing air in, there is too much airflow around the hotend and the part. This may cause difficultly in getting the hotend up to temperature. It may also aggravate part warpage.
I have also applied a piece of Kapton tape to cover the gap between the bottom of the duct on the shroud and the carriage to try to eliminate airflow in the hotend area even more. I strongly advise doing this - it works. Thermal heatsink compound applied to the heatsink (and in my case to the extra thermal barrel heatsink) greatly improves the heat transfer and significantly improves the potential for printing PLA.
I used DOW 340 Silicone heatsink compound, but if you have some Arctic Silver lying around, use that! I sliced this with Slic3r and set the support material overhang threshold to 74 degrees. This will leave the uppermost layers of the duct unsupported, but it should bridge OK. I also used a 3mm brim around the part. Note the small cutouts with radiused edges I've put on the right side for routing the thermistor wires. I tried to size the fan mounting holes so that the original screws could be used and they would self-thread into ABS.

author: Sparkydk1

title: BMW e90/92 Cell Phone Car Mount

description.text:
I just released version 2.0. Check it out because it's so much better. I released two different 2.0 variations that mount differently. I personally use the SLOTMOUNT version, it's lower profile, works great and it positioned higher. 
Both 2.0 version have a different phone holder style. It uses less material and there isn't a front brace which means it doesn't block the charging cable for portrait mounted phones.
The slot mount version slides into a small slit just above the hazard lights button, instead of the original design which clipped lower around the center air vents. The slot mount has three tabs. One middle wide one, and two outer narrow ones (see photo). What you have to do is bend them in opposite directions to create a leaf spring. I did this by taking a lighter, applying a bit of heat and then bending them. 
Lastly I've included a version of each that doesnt need screws to attach the phone mount side to the car mount side. I is meant to be glued.

This is heavily inspired by this design, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:271943. The main difference is mine is designed to be easy to attach/detach as I don't want it up there all of the time (just on long trips). It's also better hidden. And it's got a different connection design for the phone to vent mount I started a remix but ultimately did my own design from scratch as it was simply easier to work with. I've redesigned the phone mount to fit BlackBerry Passport and Z30, but it can easily be modified to work with any phone. It's easier to install and remove because I've added lower resistance clips and a detach lever. This helps ensure you don't scratch anything up because you aren't having to force the clips on. Likewise I found the above mention model difficult to remove. You'd have to use a tool like your keys or a screw drive to get it off. The detach lever is well hidden. It basically stays in line with the vent louvers and then makes a bend for the thumb tab to poke out. You might have to extend this lever depending on your phone's length. (I really hope to make this design parametric at some point so people can use this without having to worry about rework. It'd like it to be customizable for any car for that matter.) The phone mount can attach to the vent mount by using two M3 screws (hint: hard drive screws are M3). If you don't use screws you can use krazy glue to secure the two pieces together. I tested this and it works great. I recommend attaching a piece of foam to the back of the unit to ensure a more firm mount and also for some extra protection against your dash. If you cut the foam just right it will fit snug by itself between the two mounting posts. I also recommend giving a light sand to any parts of the mount that touch your car. Such as the back of the mount. And more importantly the hooks/clips. The last thing you want is a bur or a sharp end scratching anything up. PLA probably isn't a good idea due to heat issues. ABS would probably be best. I did mine in PLA and we'll see how long it lasts me after winter. ABS in an acetone vapor bath would probably look like a really nice product.

description.text: They're the overlords of the 8 bit universe - on the rocks. They're also connectable to create your custom ice mold sheet. If your cocktail party approves, feel free to flattr this design or any derivatives. This is also a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3647 - the home world of the space invaders.

Nope, sorry - they don't work (yet?). I am just publishing this to get it out of my head and give others the chance to fix it. The surface structure of a 3D print just offers too much structure for the ice to cling to, so you will have a hard time to get them out of their mold intact. Also, the molds are quite solid this way.
Print with no raft, three base layers and three lines of perimeter for optimal waterproofness. Remove artefacts. Fill with aqueous substance of choice. Transfer to solid state. To work with the SCAD file, download the respective invader models from thing:3647.
You might want to experiment a bit with the model, material, scaling, bottom layer sizes etc. to actually get a model that is both stable and waterproof enough to freeze through, and flexible enough to release the ice cube afterwards. If you manage to get one of these out in the wild, please tell us how!

comments.text: I know this is really late, but I'm working on a similar project and I think I have a solution. My first iteration was a lot like what you have here. My second had very thin walls and "legs" that I could squeeze to flex the mold a bit, making it release the ice. Mine is a sphere in two halves, and that iteration couldn't hold water between the halves because it was so thin, but since yours is one sided, that shouldn't be a problem. I hope that helps!

title: Beer keg CO2 tank spacer with angled strap slots

description.text: Print a pair of these spacers to couple a 2.5 gallon Corny keg (8.25" diameter) with a 5# CO2 tank (5.25" diameter), using nylon cargo straps. This will keep your keg and CO2 tank together as a unit in your refrigerator, reducing the chance that your CO2 tank will tip over. description.text:
This AAA Battery Pack is modeled after an old one that broke inside a flashlight. So I took the broken Pieces and made myself a new one that I could, in the event of it breaking again however unlikely, print out new ones over and over again. This also enabled me to have extras so when I go camping and need a flashlight I already have a pre-loaded flashlight battery pack ready to go. I also figured this could come in handy since almost all new LED flashlights take these packs, and since it fits perfect in the same amount of space the old one did it was a great idea and I was surprised when no one else had made one yet.   
After Adding the old springs from the old one and a couple small threaded Computer Screws it came to life and lit up like the original.

So this was my grad project from UNSW Art and Design.
The project is all about reuse and hinges on the idea that much of the furniture/off cut materials thrown away can be made into new pieces by cutting them up and joining them back together with 3D printed connectors.
The beauty of 3D printing the connectors is that the user can input the size/shape of their materials into the thingiverse customiser model and print a connector that exact size!
The system is supposed to be a bit of an exercise in open design, users can muck around with the different connectors, improve upon them or create new ones with simple 3D modelling.
I think (hope!) it's a fairly easy system to understand, basically there's the housing pieces and the plugs. The cutout in the plug can be sized to the material to be inserted and then the plug is plugged into any of the housings to make all kind of shapes.
I don't feel like its a completed project yet, there's definitely still room for improvement. It feels like the beginning of something better.
Feedback of any kind would of course be most appreciated :)

title: Toilet Roll Space / Square peg adaptor for round holes.

description.text:
This device is designed for a particular type of paper towel holder that we use for toilet rolls in our office.  
It has an 8mm square rod in a "U" shape hanging sideways from a protruding wall fixture.  
when two rolls are placed on it, and one roll is pulled, both rolls spin - this is designed to prevent the friction from the first roll, from unrolling the second.  
However - I'm sure you will find many more useful applications for this round disc with a square hole - such as adapting a square leg into a round hole, or as a dummy i-chin coin.

title: Microsoft Lifecam HD3000 Camera mount (requires mods to camera)

description.text:
Recently I designed a camera system based on a Raspberry Pi, to keep tabs on my workplace (100 foot high fire tower)  
I modified a HD3000 Lifecam to do this, and potted the circuit board into epoxy resin to keep it water proof.  
This mounting system was designed to attach to a magnet and allow a small amount of adjustment of the finished product, while remaining reasonably discreet. Photo attached.  
I'll also be uploading my adapter shims to fit a raspberry Pi into a Tupperware clone container.

author: Dranoweb

title: Prusa i3 x-axis Idler with Tensioner

description.text: After building a Prusa i3 rework by eMotion-Tech, I found the x axis idler block to be weak, and the printer in desperate need of a way to adjust belt tension. It uses two bearing that were salvaged from a hard drive and a 5mm pin cut down to be just short enough to fit inside the pocket. A 5mm bolt will slide into the bearing pocket and through the outer block where a nut can be fitted and used to adjust the tension on the belt. This is a direct bolt in swap, you shouldn't have to modify the belt in any way. I am using mechanical endstops, so it does not have provisions for the optical endstops like the part it replaces.

THIS IS A FAILED EXPERIMENT!
This was one of my earliest designs, and was designed to solve a problem that arose from incorrect construction of Wade's extruder.
I'm only leaving this here for historical purposes. I've printed a few versions of this, but this one is NOT TESTED.
however the design is based on measurements from previous prints. YOU WILL NEED:
2mm drill bit
Pederstool drill OR:
Some way to keep your drill perpendicular.
countersink tool OR:
large drill bit (for finishing entry hole) As I was unable to find hobbed bolts, nor could I be bothered to print a bolt hobbing jig, I chose to use a knurling tool on my Prusa i3 extruder (wade's extruder) The problem is now that the filament will walk off the bolt, if the bearing tensions are even a tiny bit unbalanced. This little gadget is designed to fit between the tension bolts on a wade's extruder, with allowance for 5mm springs over the bolts as well. This should keep the filament on track, and make loading a bit easier too. I also have a roll of ninja flex TPE filament. I'll be testing to see if this improves performance too. This will require drilling out with a 2mm drill bit for 1.,75mm filament, 3.25 or 3.5mm drill for 3mm filament.

title: 6 to 8 mm nut test for clearance.   .2mm steps.

description.text:
I had to make a nut trap for a tiny nut that fit on a 2 mm machine screw. I made this so I could print out all sizes between 6 and 8 mm in .2 mm steps. sizes from smallest to largest are as follows. 6 6.2 6.4 6.6 6.8 7 7.2 7.4 7.6 7.8 8
6.4 was a force fit, 6.6 was a snug fit and 6.8 was a loose fit. Your mileage will vary due to your settings and temperatures but if you need to know what size hole for a small nut as your printer is set up right now this is a handy and quick print that uses very little plastic.

http://www.sparkfun.com/products/9205 Do you wish your ClockIt mounted to your bedframe? (Note, I know this works on most beds at CMU and Elon Universities, you might want to check yours to make sure they have 3/8" metal pins in the risers to hold your bed at any of a number of 3" separated heights.)

Print one ClockIt holder, and one Bedframe Hook.
Glue together (I used JB Weld)
Mount your ClockIt (Mine is not currently glued in, you might need a little hot glue or something.  Be really nifty, and bolt it in place.  [This requires a few more bolts and some modifications to the inventor file, I don't have the bolts, or great luck with small holes, so I left it as is.  Works well for me.])
Hook on to your bed.
Rejoice.
Do you have other things you wish you could mount to your bedframe?
Make holders with a 1" X .25" hole in the back, glue in hooks, rejoice.

25CMLED is a DIY LED torch light for makers.
It consist of an aluminum profile with SMD LEDs and a number of 3D printed parts that serve as battery pack holder and grip. This thing is presented by blink*gestalten (www.blinkgestalten.de). Part List:
  • 6 SMD LEDs
  • approx. 1 m copper band (acting as circuit path)
  • some wires
  • toggle switch
  • battery clip
  • battery pack for 6 AA cells
  • 3D printed parts (battery pack holders and grip)
  • 4 M3 screws, 10 mm
  • 1 M3 screw, 16 mm
  • 1 M3 screw, 18 mm
  • aluminum profile (length 25 cm, profile dimensions B x H1 x H2: 40 mm x 15 mm x 40 mm)
    • Note that the complete assembly instructions are beyond the scope of this thinigiverse thing. Therefore the instructions cover only the assembly of the 3D printed parts. If you want to learn how to assemble the SMD LEDs, feel free to visit my LED lamp workshop at FabLab Munich (http://wiki.fablab-muenchen.de/display/WIKI/Programm). Note: the design was inspired by the torch light described in this book:
    http://www.amazon.de/LED-Wohnraumlicht-Band-1-1-S-Leuchtenberg-ebook/dp/B00C1NLIDM/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1420539212&sr=8-2&keywords=wohnraumlicht

Note that the complete assembly instructions are beyond the scope of this thinigiverse thing. Therefore the instructions cover only the assembly of the 3D printed parts. If you want to learn how to assemble the SMD LEDs, feel free to visit my LED lamp workshop at FabLab Munich (http://wiki.fablab-muenchen.de/display/WIKI/Programm). Instructions for 25CMLED assembly:
  • Saw an aluminum profile to the appropriate length (25 cm)
  • Chamfer the aluminum profile
  • Create a paper drilling template (print file DrillingTemplate.svg) and stick it to the aluminum profile bottom
  • Mark hole positions using the drilling template
  • Drill holes and chamfer them
  • Mount the SMD LEDs - this is a more complex process ... it's too complex to describe it here. Just visit my workshop in FabLab Munich to learn how to build the SMD LED lamp!
  • Print the 3D parts
  • Sink the holes in the 3D parts using a drill
  • Slip part 3 (the grip) into part 2 (the battery holder) and screw it using a M3 16 mm and M3 18 mm counter-sunk screw
  • Screw the battery holder parts to the aluminum profile using
    four M3 10mm counter-sunk screws
  • Solder two long wires to the toggle switch and mount the toggle switch.
  • Solder the wires coming from the SMD LEDs and the toggle switch wires to the battery clip
  • Mount the battery clip
    • You are done!

title: 10 to 12 nut clearance test by .2mm steps

description.text: Same as the others, this covers 10, 10.2, 10.4, 10.6  yadda yadda yadda...up to 12 mm. Design stuff that fits hardware you got laying around. See pic for results. A snug fitting nut and a dab of crazy glue or epoxy add a whole level of possibilities to your designs. You can even heat them up and push them into a tight spot for a glue free connection. Plastic home made parts with metal threads. Wheee!!! This one takes a little longer to print. When you print it out it's about 134 mm long. Shoppers drug mart "get" brand glue stick on glass if you're curious. This test fit stick and the other three I posted will let you figure out what the perfect hole is for hex nuts from M2 thread all the way to M8 bolts and threaded rod.

No responsibility will be taken for lost sleep because of text messages, emails, or internet wanderings on your cellphone now conveniently located next to your head. You're in college, you don't need sleep. If you use your Nexus One as an alarm clock, no responsibility will be taken for you missing classes because your alarm clock is now located conveniently next to your head, making it easy to turn off and go back to sleep. You're in college, you don't need to go to class. Sleep and going to class are both Good Things.

remixed_from.title: Cheap Roller Carriage for DLT-180(Chinese Kossel 2020)

description.text:
In my quest of building a Maxi kossel with 2020 extrusion,
i've tested these http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:566093 with POW shower roller. i found that the carrier wobbling a little bit. i've try with 608 bearing, but metal on metal is too noisy for me. So instead of paid 80€ for proper delrin rollers. I've try to made my own with a bunch of MR83-ZZ bearings. theses rollers can be printed in pla or flex. PLA works but i try to make the kossel as quiet as possible. (ecco)Flex roller a smoother and make no noise but even at 100% infill it have a tendecy to bend and make delta printer inacurate. ps: Print settings

This plugin does not work with 2.57 use 2.56 , code update coming soon . Updated version of the gcode script from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6103 I have taken MR's instruction and converted this to a menu item. With the plugin installed there is now a File | import | gcode item. This brings up a file browser. So there is no more messy text editing. This will continue to be available at https://github.com/zignig/blender-gcode-reader I'm looking into parsing skeinforge comments , and dealing with 5D and stringy bits.

201102070914
blender gcode reader
reads reprap gcode files into blender 2.5 for rendering and visualization Instructions get latest blender http://www.blender.org/download/get-256-beta/ open blender
Select
File Menu
User Preferences CTL-ALT-U
Select The Add-Ons Tab
Press the Install Add-On Button ( down the bottom )
install file io_import_gcode.py you just downloaded.
the add on then needs to be activated.
find it in the list ( search for gc ) and select the tick box on the right hand side. If you want to keep it click to Save As Default Now there should be a menu item of
File
Import
Reprap GCode (.gcode) Select a file , watch the console for progress. Bask in the glory of your awesome small plastic thing. Simon

Hello, J'ai récupéré à la poubelle (!!!!!) une superbe bouteille de whisky Ballantine's de 3 litres ; une bouteille de bar car l'étiquette est retournée mais malheureusement le bouchon était fendu.
Un petit coup d'imprimante 3D et le tour est joué.
Un bouchon tout beau, tout neuf.

A simple push stick to keep your fingers safely away from the blade when cutting small pieces on a table saw or router table.  Print 3 or 4 and keep them near every tool where you might use them.  
They're designed to be a bit 'springy' on purpose, to keep nice steady pressure on the work piece.  Keeping the wood tight to the table and tight to the fence is critical in making accurate and safe cuts.  Couple these with a featherboard and you're going to be in real good shape.  (maybe I should model a printable featherboard?)  I use the yellow plastic Milescraft featherboard, available on Amazon for under $15.  
They could be a bit larger but they actually work pretty well.  My saw uses a 9" blade so these are fine, but if you have a 12" saw you're probably going to want something bigger.  I already nicked one of them with the blade on my table saw.  It took a small chip out of the plastic but the push stick still woks fine.  
Printed on a Replicator 2X in ABS.  I didn't want the stiffness or hardness of PLA to be a problem if the stick comes in contact with the saw blade.  The slightly softer ABS seemed like the better choice.  
I may try printing these again, but in in polystyrene (also know as the ABS support material the dissolved in limonene) because it's even softer than ABS.  I'd like for it not to chip, but to simply be cut, if/when the stick gets into the blade.

I think I printed these on standard quality, with something like 5 shells and 25% infill.  The structural rails are meant to be springy but not overly stiff, while not being too wimpy.  They sometimes try to curl up because there isn't much surface area touching the plate, so make sure you level your build plate really well (use my leveling pattern!), and use some ABS glue/slurry or Aquanet on the Kapton tape before printing to keep the ends from warping.

A geometric egg with a lattice for the shell.

Must be rotated 180 deg to print on the flat base.  Prints well standard size and at 195% with 0.15mm layers, 2 shells, and 15% infill.

title: Wire management bracket for NI DAQ card modules

description.text:
Some of our test rigs have huge numbers of thermocouples or other sensors.  The management of 32 wires entering one DAQ card can be a nightmare.  The cards do not have a good system for dealing with this, and the existing padded metal clamping bar doesn't do a very good job securing all the wires.  There are always some getting pinched and some still loose.  
Bolt this bracket to the card, ignore the clamp bar, and use zip-ties to bundle and secure the wires to the bracket.
Print with the disc-shaped feet against the plate.  Cut off the little discs afterward.

author: jmcskixc

description.text: A key chain fob SD card holder.  You can configure the dimensions and depth, hole size etc.  This is my first model.

By default this is setup to fit 2 SD cards.  
There is a "hinge" so to speak that requires either a flexible material, or to use the hot end to make two 90 degree folds.  I imagined a simpler design, but it would have required a 180 degree fold that I'm pretty sure would not happen.
I had trouble printing out a similar but solid SD card holder since it required vertical printing which yielded bad results on my printer.  Therefore I designed this to be printed horizontally, which prints much nicer, and then for the two sides to be bent up at 90 degrees.
Name says it all.  Tubular spacers for mounting a DAQ chassis to a flat surface.  Allows airflow and wires to pass beneath the unit.

Our Axis dome cameras tend to get knocked around in the lab and the dome-shaped lens gets all scratched up.  The faceplates can be replaced but they're not cheap.  (we use them on tripods, etc.  See my Axis Tripod Mount)  This cowl gets glued to the faceplate and protects the lens when the thing falls on its face.  Also provides a bit of shielding from side-lighting.

A-frame carrier for those extra-large filament spools.  
Print 2 of each part except the axle.  Print with the disc-shaped feet against the build plate, and cut off the feet afterward.  Slide the cross members up into the slots in the bottom of the A-frames with a little glue.  Attach rubber feet to the bottom of the cross members if you want.  Slip the bushings into the holes in the spool and stick an axle of some kind through the whole thing.  I used an old screwdriver for an axle, but I also modeled a quick axle that should work OK.

description.text:
I have a WiFi router sitting on the edge of the server/printer/other computer stuff rack, and it's sitting right next to the server ready to fall off at any time.
So I modelled this up and have yet to test it, but it should work. It prints in two parts that glue together. It has a lip on the edge. All I have to do is clip the finished and glued-together thing on the rack, and then I have a nice little holder.

It's made specifically for my rack and router, but I decided to upload it (part because it's something that can be made and part that I neede my thing for Day 8).
Print one part, mirror, then print again. Glue together and clip onto rack. Place WiFi router on top. Now you won't have a Humpty Router* having a great fall anymore.
*Yes, yes, I know, I couldn't resist...

author: jmcskixc

description.text: Simple, two part TP holder which attaches to the wall with two 3M "Command" Strips. Video: http://youtu.be/Mz6J5ZKoSy8

Roll is 113 mm tall, while the end cap is 15 mm tall (along axis). I used 20% octagonal infill for strength and a 1 mm wall thickness because I wanted the adhesive strips to be well anchored to the base of the holder.   
Printed both parts in 6 hours with 10 m of 1.75 mm PLA. On the end plate, the "anchor" face is printed down, which may require some support in the anchor detail. On the roll, the flange is printed first, so no support required. The dovetail is at 70 degrees, which prints well.  
I chipped out the support in the anchor detail and added some white paint to make it more obvious.  
The dovetail worked well, but needed 5 minutes of sanding to get the fit just right. Next time, I might increase my clearance to avoid this (I would use 0.5 mm rather than 0.25 mm).  
I attached the command strips to the holder, cleaned the tile wall with acetone,  then pushed it into place. It is very sturdy and looks solid.

Update: Generated a smaller STL file for the part that wouldn't preview.  
We have unusual walls in the men's room at the office, and there was no good way to use a normal tension rod to mount a second shower curtain, in order to create a changing area outside the stall shower.  I designed and printed these pivoting brackets to allow the rod to be mounted across the area at an angle, giving us more space in there.  
Assemble with some self-tapping screws, leaving them just loose enough to allow the mount to pivot until you get it into position and screwed into the wall.  Then you can snug down the pivot screws if you want, but it's not necessary.  Also you can remove the pivot screws to release the curtain rod easily if needed.  
We used one of those curtain rods that you twist to expand to the length you need.  I cut the rubber bumpers off the ends so it would fit in the sockets of the mount.

I made this guide to keep the filament lined up with the hobbed markings on the extruder bolt. I find the arc of the filament from unspooling would tend to push itself off the markings and then my print would suffer. I tried other guides, but most of them were a plate with a hole which did work but put too much resistence on the filament causing the same issue. This one is very small, slides on the bolts of the extruder's resistence arm, and floats so it can move a little if needed. This worked great with the least amount of resistence. It only takes a few minutes to print it and try one.

Unbolt the arm that holds the bearing to the hobbed bolt.
Slide it on
I found with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62386 filament guide and any spool bracket that includes skatboard bearings, all issues with filament feeding are gone and i get great prints.
